question.text: Arrange the various respiratory volumes in ascending order.

options.text: Tidal Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Residual Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Expiratory Reserve Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Inspiratory Reserve Volume
Tidal Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Expiratory Reserve Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Residual Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Inspiratory Reserve Volume
Tidal Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Residual Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Inspiratory Reserve Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Expiratory Reserve Volume
Residual Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Tidal Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Inspiratory Reserve Volume <math><mo>→</mo></math> Expiratory Reserve Volume

solution.text: Tidal Volume (TV): Volume of air inspired or expired during a normal respiration. It is approx. 500 mL., i.e., a healthy man can inspire or expire approximately 6000 to 8000 mL of air per minute. Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV): Additional volume of air, a person can inspire by a forcible inspiration. This averages 2500 mL to 3000 mL. Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): Additional volume of air, a person can expire by a forcible expiration. This averages 1000 mL to 1100 mL. Residual Volume (RV): Volume of air remaining in the lungs even after a forcible expiration. This averages 1100 mL to 1200 mL.
